Graphical abstract An increase in the Cu content leads to an increase in selectivity for higher alcohols and CO2 in the conversion of synthesis gas. The effect of the substitution of copper ions by titanium ions in LaCuxTi1-xO3 (x = 0.4–0.8) mixed oxide on physicochemical and catalytic properties in syngas conversion was studied. The activation and catalytic testing were accompanied by reduction of part of copper ions and destruction of the perovskite structure leading to the removal of titanium and copper cations. An increase in the titanium content leads to a decrease in the proportion of reduced copper with the preservation of the defective perovskite-like oxide substrate. The application of KIT-6 silica for increasing the surface area essentially enhanced catalytic efficiency of the system. The main product of syngas conversion was methanol; its formation selectivity on the synthesized mixed oxides is comparable to the selectivity on conventional CuZnAl oxide catalyst. With increasing copper content in the samples, the selectivity for higher alcohols increases and contribution of water-gas shift reaction to the total CO conversion rate grows. Keywords Copper-containing perovskites LaCuxTi1-xO3 Template synthesis Syngas conversion Methanol synthesis 1 Introduction Synthesis of alcohols from syngas, which is obtained by gasification of biomass, is one of the methods used to produce biofuel [1]. Alcohols can be employed as additives to conventional fuel [2] or as a special type of fuel [3] in both the internal combustion engines and fuel cells for generation of electricity [4]. The application of alcohols as a fuel has significant advantages over conventional types of fuel because it provides carbon neutrality and reduces the emission of soot, CO and NOx; it is important also that alcohols can be produced from renewable resources. In addition, methanol has the highest octane number among alcohols and a high latent heat of vaporization, which ensure a more efficient operation of internal combustion engines [3]. Since 1960s, methanol has been produced from syngas with the use of CuZnAl/Cr oxide catalysts, which are highly active at moderate temperatures and pressures and highly selective toward methanol. Such catalysts are synthesized by thermal treatment of mixed hydroxocarbonates at moderate temperatures with subsequent reductive activation of the resulting oxides [5]. The promotion of copper catalysts with alkali or rare-earth (RE) metals makes it possible to increase the methanol yield or shift the distribution of products toward higher alcohols [6], which are valuable chemical products. Therewith, high activity of such copper-containing catalysts may be caused by the binding of the highly dispersed copper phase to the RE oxide substrate. Among variants of copper stabilization in the mixed oxide is the introduction of copper ions in its perovskite-like ABO3 structure. In this structure, it is possible to substitute Cu cations in position B, which would allow to deliberately control physicochemical and catalytic properties of the system. The possibility to synthesize copper-containing perovskites with the composition LaCuxTi1-xO3 by the citrate method was demonstrated in [7]; these perovskites showed considerable activity and high selectivity to methanol in the syngas conversion reaction [8]. However, such samples can be used only as model catalysts due to their low specific surface area [9]. In this work, we studied the effect exerted on physicochemical and catalytic properties of the LaCuxTi1-xO3 (х = 0.4–0.8) system by an increase in specific surface area of the samples synthesized with the use of mesoporous silica KIT-6 as a template. 2 Experimental The following reagents were used in the study: La(NO3)3×6H2O (chemically pure, Reakhim, Specs 6-09-4676-83), Cu(NO3)2 39.5 % solution (without S, ultra pure, Reakhim, GOST 4163-78), Ti(i-OC3H7)4 (pure, PromKhimPerm, Specs 2423-008-50284764-2006), citric acid (analytically pure, Ecros, GOST 365269), NaOH (chemically pure, Ecros, GOST 4328-77), C2H5OH (Reakhim, GOST R 51999-2002). Solutions were prepared using distilled water. 2.1 Synthesis of samples To increase the specific surface area of samples, they were synthesized using mesoporous silica KIT-6, which was obtained by a technique reported in [10]. All the samples synthesized for the study (LaCuxTi1-xO3/KIT-6, x = 0.4−0.8 and La2CuO4/KIT-6 as well as LaCu0.5Ti0.5O3 and La2CuO4) were obtained by the citrate method. For this purpose, 0.02 mol of lanthanum nitrate and the corresponding amounts of copper nitrate and titanium tetraisopropylate as well as 15.4 g of citric acid were dissolved in 60 mL of ethanol at 40 °C for 1 h. The resulting suspension was added to 6 g of KIT6 in 100 mL of water, held under continuous stirring at 35 °C for 24 h, and then evaporated at 95 °C to obtain a thick gel. The gel was dried at 100 °C and then powdered. The powders were subjected to thermal treatment in air at 500 °C for 3 h and then at 700 °C for 4 h. According to HRTEM data (Fig. 1 ), particles of the synthesized samples have a size of 100−200 nm and are surrounded by the matrix of KIT6 support, which is consistent with the data reported in [11]. To increase the surface area of samples accessible for catalytic investigation, a considerable part of KIT6 was then removed by holding in a 7% solution of NaOH at 75 °C for 15 min, which was followed by washing with water at 90 °C on a filter. The elemental analysis showed that silicon content in the synthesized samples after washing did not exceed 18 wt.%, while sodium content was below 0.02 wt.%. The removal of a greater portion of KIT6 silica does not seem reasonable (Table 1 ), because the fraction of removed KIT-6 decreases in each successive dissolution step along with a stronger destruction of the synthesized perovskite. This is caused primarily by dissolution of copper with the formation of a soluble complex Na2[Cu(OH)4] in the solution, which is indicated by the blue color of the filtrate. Therewith, a part of KIT-6 silica may be incorporated in the perovskite phase. Quantitative analysis was performed by means of atomic emission spectroscopy (AES) on an Optima 4300 DV (Perkin Elmer) instrument. The total accessible surface area of samples was calculated by the BET method from the nitrogen adsorption isotherms obtained on an ASAP-2400 (Micrometrics, USA) setup after vacuum treatment of samples at 150 °C. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) was carried out on a D-8 (Bruker) diffractometer with a Cu-Kα source (λ =1.5418 Å) using point-by-point scanning with a 0.05° step in the 2θ range 20−80°. Interplanar distances were measured with an accuracy Δd = ±0.01 Å. Differential thermal analysis (DTA) in hydrogen was performed on a Netzsch STA-409 unit in a flowing mixture of hydrogen and argon (1:1) fed at a rate of 40 mL/min with heating to 900 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. 2.2 Electron spectroscopy of diffuse reflectance (DR-UV–vis) The electronic state of samples before and after catalytic testing was examined by DR-UV–vis spectroscopy on a UV-2501 PC (Shimadzu) spectrophotometer with an ISR240 A diffuse reflectance attachment. The powdered samples were placed in a quartz cuvette with the optical path length 2 mm. DR-UV–vis spectra were recorded using BaSO4 as the reflectance standard in the wavelength range 190−900 nm (11000–53000 cm–1). The obtained diffuse reflection factors were transformed into absorption coefficients using the Kubelka-Munk function F R = (1-R) 2 2R , and wavelengths were converted to wavenumbers. All UV–vis data are presented in the coordinates: Kubelka–Munk function, F(R) – wavenumber [12]. 2.3 Differential dissolution method (DD) Differential dissolution of the catalyst samples under consideration was carried out in the dynamic dissolution mode using a stoichiograph equipped with an inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (BAIRD, the Netherlands). In the stoichiographic titration mode [13], the dissolution started from a 0.01 M HCl aqueous solution, then passing to 1.2 M HCl and 3.8 M HF solutions, with the temperature gradually raised from 20 to 80 °C. The composition of samples was determined from the spectral lines of elements: Cu – 324.7 nm, La – 379.0 nm, and Ti – 337.2 nm, with sensitivity 10–3μg/mL and error 5 %rel. Since oxygen cannot be determined by the indicated method, stoichiometric formulas of the corresponding phases are presented in a fragmentary form, without oxygen [14]. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) studies were performed on a JEM-2010 (JEOL) electron microscope with accelerating voltage 200 kV and limiting resolution 0.14 nm. Samples were deposited onto the carbon substrates fixed on copper grids. Catalytic testing of samples in the syngas conversion reaction was carried out on a flow laboratory setup. The composition of the initial mixture was CO:H2 = 1:2 and 10 % nitrogen (an internal standard). Measurements were made using the 2 g samples with the grain size 0.14−0.25 mm at 240°C and 2 MPa, GHSV = 500–1090 h–1. All the samples were reduced at 270 °C. Upon testing, the composition of initial and final gas mixtures was analyzed on a carbon column; the produced hydrocarbons were removed on a zeolite column and not taken into account. Chromatographic analysis of light hydrocarbons C1-C8 was made separately on a zeolite column. Liquid products were analyzed on a capillary column with the SE-54 stationary liquid phase. Testing was conducted for 1819 h in the periodic mode. Liquid products were accumulated and analyzed after testing. Catalytic properties in water-gas shift reaction (WGSR) were studied in a flow setup at atmospheric pressure, composition of the mixture CO:H2O:H2 = 8:42:50 at a steam/gas ratio equal to 0.5−0.6, sample weight 1.1–1.5 g, and GHSV 5400–14700 h–1. The reaction was carried out over the catalyst mixed with quartz sand having the same grain size and a similar volume. Activity of the samples in water-gas shift reaction was characterized by the apparent rate constant of the direct reaction, which was obtained in the first order approximation with respect to CO with no allowance for reversibility of the reaction. CO conversion was 4-48%. The apparent activation energy Ea of the reaction was estimated from the temperature dependence of the reaction rate constant in the region of 190−270 °C; the Ea measurement error was 4 kJ/mol. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of samples The LaCuxTi1-xO3/KIT-6 composition of samples with x = 0.4−0.8 was chosen because stable solid solutions with the perovskite structure can exist [7]. The interaction of metal cations with the KIT-6 silica during the synthesis by citrate method is unlikely owing to high acidity of the medium. At x < 0.3, the LaCuxTi1-xO3 solid solutions decompose to form mixed phases of lanthanum and titanium (IV) oxides. The La2CuO4 phase was chosen as the reference sample. Other phases for x = 1 – LaCuO3- δ [15] and La2Cu2O5 [16] – can only be synthesized by other complicated instrumental methods under high oxygen pressure, so they are not considered in this paper. It is seen in the diffraction patterns (Fig. 2 ) that when x grows, not only the main perovskite phase with the La2CuTiO6 structure (ICSD PDF2 00-045-0635) is observed in the synthesized samples, but there occurs also an increase in the content of the La2CuO4 phase (ICSD PDF2 00-030-0487), which becomes predominant in the sample with x = 0.8. The sample with x = 0.4 contains the lanthanum oxide La2O3 phase (ICSD PDF2 01-083-1345). For samples with x = 0.8 and La2CuO4, weak reflections of the CuO phase (ICSD PDF2 00-002-1040) are also observed. As follows from XRD data (Fig. 3 ), solid solutions of perovskite structure with the composition LaCuxTi1-xO3 exist only in the limited range of the copper to titanium cationic ratio. In the diffraction pattern of sample with x = 0.5, only the phase with the perovskite structure is observed. At other Cu/Ti ratios, the formation of perovskite phase is accompanied by the formation of additional phases containing cations that do not enter the perovskite structure, particularly, lanthanum oxide, La2CuO4 and probably copper oxide. DTA data (Table 2 ) of samples in the hydrogen-containing mixture confirm the mixed phase composition for all the synthesized samples of LaCuxTi1-xO3/KIT-6 series. According to Fig. 4 , two main thermal effects are observed for the samples in the region of 200−230 °C; they correspond to the reduction of copper from two phases: La2CuO4 at 200 °C and perovskite at ∼ 225 °C. The third thermal effect of the copper reduction from copper oxide at 187 °C is weakly pronounced for all the samples except one with x = 0.4; this is a single effect for the indicated sample. It seems that in this sample copper is not reduced from the perovskite phase. A comparison of DTA data on the weight loss upon reduction with the chemical analysis data (upon reduction of only Cu2+ cations, ΔmDTА ≤ 0.25×wAES(Cu) is expected) indicates that the observed weight loss is related not only with the reduction of copper in the synthesized samples but also with the removal of hydroxyl and carboxyl groups [17]. A small mass loss should be noted for a bulk sample with x = 0.5. It is likely that the presence of the KIT-6 matrix contributes to a deeper destruction of the perovskite structure. The differential dissolution (DD) method was employed to determine the cationic composition of different oxide phases in the samples with x = 0.4, 0.7 and La2CuO4, synthesized with KIT-6 (Table 3 ). In all the samples, a part of titanium is present as the individual oxide that may be partially encapsulated by KIT-6 silica, which is testified by the dissolution of free titanium at two different steps. As x is raised in the initial samples, the atomic content of copper increases to Cu/La = 1/2 in the three-component phase. In this method, the attribution to a certain phase is based on a constant ratio of the content of a pair of cations during one dissolution step. For this reason it is difficult to conclude whether the observed phases have the indicated composition or they are a mixture of phases since the ratio Cu/La = 1/2 is fulfilled for both the perovskite phase La2CuTiO6 and the La2CuO4 phase. The La/Cu ratio obtained for the La2CuO4 sample is within the measurement error. A small part of copper and lanthanum cations in all the initial samples occurs as oxides, which is also confirmed by the observed weak thermal effect of CuO reduction. The DD study of these samples revealed the formation of the La1Cu0.25Ti0.1 phase after catalytic testing in the reducing syngas medium. Presumably, this is the defect perovskite phase because the relative content of this phase in the sample with x = 0.4 is close to the content of initial perovskite phase. Since the reduction of copper from the structure of perovskite or from La2CuO4 is not observed for this sample, it can be concluded that in initial sample the La1Cu0.24Ti0.55 phase is represented by the perovskite that loses titanium cations upon catalytic testing. A comparison of XRD and DTA data suggests that the La1Cu0.5Ti0.02 phase observed in the initial sample consists of perovskite and La2CuO4, the latter being the prevailing component. Most likely, in the reducing medium a part of free highly dispersed titanium oxide enters the La2CuO4 structure to form a defect perovskite with the mixed composition La1Cu0.25Ti0.1. Therewith, the phase with the perovskite structure that occurred in the initial sample is partially retained. Hence, it follows that during the catalytic testing all Cu-containing phases can be the source of metal copper particles. An increased content of free lanthanum oxide in the samples after catalytic testing confirms that copper is reduced from the lanthanum-containing substrate. Copper particles emerging in the process may be incorporated in the lanthanum-containing oxide substrate and dissolve simultaneously with it, which follows from DD data since the content of free copper oxide in the initial samples is close to that after catalytic testing. It is also possible that copper enters the structure of the lanthanum-containing oxide substrate during the reoxidation of the sample [19]; however, it was not studied here. It should be noted also that copper oxide in the samples after catalytic testing is formed due to the oxidation of Cu0 particles by air oxygen. Copper particles emerging from free copper oxide may be bound to free lanthanum oxide or surrounded by the KIT-6 substrate, and this will determine their catalytic properties. XRD data obtained by the analysis of samples after catalytic testing (Fig. 5 ) are consistent with the above reasoning. Thus, for the sample with x = 0.5, along with the perovskite phase one can observe the lanthanum oxide phase, which is absent in the diffraction pattern of the initial sample. The destruction of LaCuxTi1-xO3/KIT6 samples upon catalytic testing leads to amorphization of the phase, which becomes more pronounced with an increase in the copper content; so, XRD data for the samples with x = 0.6−0.8 are low informative and are not reported here. Comparing the XRD and DD data of perovskite samples after catalytic tests, we can conclude that an increase in the titanium content leads to a decrease in the proportion of reduced copper with the preservation of a defective perovskite-like oxide substrate. DR-UV–vis spectra (Fig. 6 a) for the series of initial oxide samples with x = 0.5−0.8 show the absorption band (a.b.) at 13800 cm–1, which can be attributed to the d-d transition of Cu2+ cations in a tetragonal distorted octahedral environment in the La2CuTiO6 perovskite structure [20]. For the sample with x = 0.8, there is an additional broad a.b. at 16300 cm–1, which may be assigned to Cu2+ cations in a square-planar coordination that are stabilized in the La2CuO4 structure. These results well agree with the XRD data, which indicate that the sample with x = 0.8 comprises two oxide phases: La2CuTiO6 and La2CuO4. However, the DR-UV–vis spectrum of the La2CuO4 reference sample contains a broad a.b. with the maximum at 17800 cm–1 and a low-intensity shoulder at 13800 cm–1. The absorption band at 17800 cm–1 may be caused by the d-d transition of Cu2+ cations in a square-planar coordination in the La2CuO4 structure. It seems more correct to attribute the shoulder at 13800 cm–1 in the reference sample to Cu2+ cations stabilized in CuO [21]. First, because the XRD study revealed a small admixture of the CuO phase in this sample, but no perovskite. Second, according to [21], the CuO phase is characterized by the appearance of the first a.b. with the maximum at 13900 cm–1, and the band gap value for CuO is usually equal to 1.2 eV. For the sample with x = 0.4, the DR-UV–vis spectrum strongly differs from all other samples. This sample has the lowest content of the highly dispersed phase, which dissolves, according to DD data, under milder conditions (see Table 3). However, the presence of two broad absorption bands with poorly resolved maxima in the region of 13800 and 22500 cm–1 makes it difficult to determine reliably the state of copper in this sample. Fig. 6(b) displays DR-UV–vis spectra of samples after the reaction. The analysis shows that all the samples have a broad a.b. in the region of 13000−17000 cm–1, which according to [22] may correspond to the resonance absorption of electromagnetic radiation (RAER) by conduction electrons of metallic copper nanoparticles. According to [7], when x is raised from 0.4 to 0.8, a decrease in the particle size from 23.6 to 12.6 nm is expected. However, our earlier calculations [22] demonstrated that the position of RAER does not depend on the size of particles in the range from 16 to 4 nm, but essentially depends on dielectric permittivity of the environment. As was shown in [22], the stronger is the binding of metal particles to the support; the lower is the energy of RAER position, which means that a red shift of RAER is observed. The analysis of the energy of RAER position for the closely located DR-UV–vis spectra in Fig. 6(b) suggests that binding to the support increases in the samples with x from 0.4 to 0.8. Therewith, for the catalyst samples with x = 0.5 and 0.6, a low intensity a.b. at 13800 cm–1 is also observed; this band is caused by the presence of Cu2+ cations in a tetragonal distorted octahedral coordination, which are stabilized, according to XRD data, in the initial perovskite phase incompletely reduced in the catalytic reaction. However, the presence of the same a.b. for La2CuO4 may indicate the occurrence of a small CuO impurity stabilized in the intercrystallite space of the main copper-containing La2CuO4 phase. As revealed by HRTEM, the sample with x = 0.7 is predominantly the two-phase system consisting of perovskite with the composition close to LaCu0.7Ti0.3O3 and the La2CuO4 phase, which are located on SiO2 aggregates (Fig. 7 a). The particle sizes of both components are approximately similar and fall in a range of 10−30 nm. Therewith, an agglomerate may contain two crystal blocks with the common boundary (Fig. 7b). The action of the reducing reaction medium on the perovskite structure leads to catalyst stratification. Thus, several fragments of phases with different morphology and chemical composition can be distinguished in the TEM image. A residual phase is represented by a poorly crystallized perovskite (Fig. 7c) with the particle size of ca. 10−30 nm, which is surrounded by the SiO2 matrix. The predominant phase is represented by amorphized particles ca. 100 nm in size (Fig. 7d), which contain Si, La, Ti and Cu cations. Such particles do not have a crystal structure, which made it difficult to determine the exact chemical composition of this amorphous component. 3.2 Catalytic properties Catalytic properties of the synthesized samples were studied in syngas conversion (Table 4 ). In a series of LaCuxTi1-xO3/KIT-6 samples, we studied the dependence of the catalytic properties on their composition. To estimate the catalytic properties of the synthesized samples, they were compared with the catalytic properties of oxide analog of commercial CuZnAl catalyst for methanol synthesis, which was synthesized by the technique reported in [23]. Liquid products of syngas conversion on the samples under consideration are represented by alcohols with trace amounts of saturated hydrocarbons having the chain length greater than eight carbon atoms. Selectivity to hydrocarbons for all the synthesized samples did not exceed 0.1 %. The content of methanol was 95–97 %, the rest part included alcohols with the chain length up to six carbon atoms, mostly ethanol and isobutanol in a ratio close to 1:1. Since methanol prevailed in the products, other alcohols were determined with insufficient accuracy; so we did not calculate the Anderson-Schultz-Flory parameter reflecting the distribution of alcohols. The effect of lanthanum-containing substrate in the studied system resembles the effect of oxide substrate in the case of classical CuZnAl catalysts for methanol synthesis [24,25], which may show up as the decoration of Cu0 nanoparticles leading to modification of their catalytic properties. According to DR-UV–vis spectroscopy data, an increase in the copper content in the samples leads to an increase in the interaction of copper particles with an oxide substrate, which may indirectly indicate a decrease in the particle size of metallic copper [7] and, consequently, an increase in the available surface of metallic copper. This means that with an increase in the copper content, the contact time increases with the obtained close values of the total specific surface of the samples. As we see from the results, this leads to a shift in the distribution of products to higher alcohols with a corresponding increase in the formation of water, which is consumed in the water gas-shift reaction. The actual water content in the reaction products on all the synthesized samples is insignificant, less than 1 mg/gcat h because the water-gas shift reaction is far from equilibrium under the process conditions and water is consumed completely [26]. A comparison of the activation energy of water-gas shift reaction (Table 4) on the synthesized samples demonstrates that the ratio of La/Cu/Ti cations does not affect the energy state of copper particles - the activation energy is approximately the same. It should be emphasized that the selectivity for higher alcohols increases precisely with a rise of the contact time, since with an increase in the copper content in the samples (with an increase in x), the specific surface area of metallic copper available for the reaction grows. As a result, the reaction products are removed from the reaction zone more slowly, and, accordingly, already synthesized alcohols are able to re-chemisorb on the surface of copper particles with a further growth in the chain length. In this case, the direct influence of the water-gas shift reaction on the main process should be abandoned, since in the case of the synthesis of any alcohol C2+ the inequality SC2+OH > SCO2 is always observed and, in view of the contribution of the formation of CO2 as a result of the synthesis of methane and DME, it agrees with the results obtained. Additional possible explanation for the change in the selectivity to higher alcohols, as noted earlier, is the direct effect of lanthanum, which increases simultaneously with the x value according to the DR UV–vis data. This probably leads to an increase in the number of weak acid sites, which presumably promote CO dissociation and the development of the carbon chain [27,28]. On the basis of the above, the hypothesis looks very interesting that an increase in selectivity for higher alcohols occurs with an increase in the Cu/La ratio. However, in addition to lanthanum cations, the system also contains titanium and silicon cations, which are usually considered to be not so active in reactions taking place in a reduction atmosphere. However, their presence makes the system very complicated to exclude the influence of these cations on the catalytic activity of copper metallic particles. The methanol productivity per gram on LaCu0.5Ti0.5O3 and La2CuO4 samples is well below than that on the samples synthesized using mesoporous silica KIT-6. This may be caused by a lower active specific surface area of the synthesized samples related with incomplete removal of KIT6 silica. The methanol productivity per unit area of copper of the pre-reduced samples, taking into account the accuracy of catalytic measurements and estimation of the surface area of metallic copper, changes insignificantly with an increase in the copper content in the samples, similar to the data [8], and is of the same level as on the conventional CuZnAl oxide catalyst. At the same time, close values of the methanol yield per unit area of metallic copper for bulk samples and samples synthesized using KIT-6 at different CO conversion are due to different surface area of metallic copper in the reduced samples. The practical application of LaCuxTi1-xO3/KIT-6 samples does not look promising in connection with the irreversible destruction of the oxide structure of the sample and, hence, the low strength of the granules formed for catalytic testing. Among the studied samples, the most resistant to destruction is the LaCu0.4Ti0.6O3/KIT-6 sample, which is also the least active. A possible solution to the strength problem could be to use an alternative support matrix. The possibility of increasing the selectivity for higher alcohols with decreasing selectivity for CO2 for the studied system seems to be an insoluble task, because almost any copper catalyst is active in water gas-shift reaction in the presence of water vapors formed in the course of higher alcohols synthesis. A possible solution is the introduction of metals, such as cobalt, into the sample, which is considered in detail in the modern literature [29–31]. However, from a practical point of view, side water gas-shift reaction is more preferable, since otherwise oxygen is removed from CO in the form of H2O, which is difficult to remove from the resulting mixture of alcohols. 4 Conclusions In the LaCuxTi1-xO3 system, at x = 0.5−0.6 mostly the homophasic mixed oxide with the perovskite-like structure is produced. At other Cu/Ti ratios a set of oxide phases is formed. As a result of reductive activation followed by the interaction of synthesized LaCuxTi1-xO3 samples with the reaction medium, copper is successively reduced from all copper-containing oxide phases, which leads to their destruction. The produced defect perovskite phase with the mixed composition La1Cu0.25Ti0.1 is stable to destruction. The formed metallic copper particles are strongly bound to the lanthanum-containing oxide substrate, which exerts a substantial effect on their catalytic properties. The productivity of LaCuxTi1-xO3/KIT-6 in the synthesis of methanol from syngas is comparable with that of the analog of commercial CuZnAl oxide sample, although remaining inferior to it. Selectivity to methanol of the synthesized samples similarly the selectivity to methanol of CuZnAl catalyst. The application of mesoporous KIT-6 silica makes it possible to considerably increase the specific surface area of copper-containing perovskites and hence their activity. Further insights are required to discern the detailed relationship between the properties of the active component and the composition and structure of precursor. coredata.dc:description: The effect of the substitution of copper ions by titanium ions in LaCuxTi1-xO3 (x = 0.4–0.8) mixed oxide on physicochemical and catalytic properties in syngas conversion was studied. The activation and catalytic testing were accompanied by reduction of part of copper ions and destruction of the perovskite structure leading to the removal of titanium and copper cations. An increase in the titanium content leads to a decrease in the proportion of reduced copper with the preservation of the defective perovskite-like oxide substrate. The application of KIT-6 silica for increasing the surface area essentially enhanced catalytic efficiency of the system. The main product of syngas conversion was methanol; its formation selectivity on the synthesized mixed oxides is comparable to the selectivity on conventional CuZnAl oxide catalyst. With increasing copper content in the samples, the selectivity for higher alcohols increases and contribution of water-gas shift reaction to the total CO conversion rate grows.
coredata.dc:title: Syngas conversion over perovskite-like LaCuxTi1-xO3/KIT-6 catalysts
